;

;;

;

;Pomegranate Group’s Beijing headquarters is located in the Fengtai Branch Center of Zhongguancun Science and Technology Park, also known as the Pomegranate Center. ;(Visual China/Picture);

;

;"Now both parties are retreating, guaranteeing the delivery of housing, protecting the interests of owners and investors, and not giving the government Cause trouble, so try not to occupy public issues anymore."

;

;On September 15, 2023, a Southern Weekend reporter interviewed Cui Wei, chairman and major shareholder of Pomegranate Real Estate Group Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Pomegranate Group) At that time, the company gave this reply.

;

;At a media communication meeting held 4 days ago, Cui Wei knelt down in public, hoping that financial institutions would not withdraw loans due to the company’s chaos. If financial institutions cause real losses, I will jump from the 22nd floor of the Pomegranate Center where we are."

;

;At this time, nearly three months have passed since internal strife broke out in this private real estate company, which ranks among the top 100 private real estate companies in China. During this period, incidents such as Cui Wei "stealing the official seal" and the dismissal of vice chairman and second shareholder Sang Chunhua frequently aroused public opinion. Sang Chunhua was also involved in a scandalous news.

;

;After Cui Wei held a media communication meeting, Sang Chunhua also held a media communication meeting on September 14 and released a reconciliation signal at the meeting. He shouted to Cui Wei: "I am still willing to give in and let you get more until we reach an agreement and stop the dispute."

;

;The two sides have been at odds for some time. In 2021, Pomegranate Group failed to go public in Hong Kong. The next year, Sang Chunhua proposed a separation, believing that Cui Wei had not made the right decision in more than ten years and did not want to be held hostage again.

;

;Cui Wei proposed that his equity would require a 30% premium when the company was separated, but Sang Chunhua refused to accept it. Conflicts accumulated over the years are about to break out.

;

;;Exposing each other's shortcomings;

;

;In 2001, Cui Wei and Sang Chunhua cooperated to establish Beijing Agile Real Estate Development Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Agile) in Beijing; in 2008 , the two parties also established Huamei K2 Real Estate Investment Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Huamei K2), named after K2, the world’s second highest peak; in 2016, the company was renamed Pomegranate Group, aiming to be the “Apple in the real estate industry.”

;

;In the more than 20 years since its establishment, Pomegranate Group has developed more than 90 projects in more than 30 cities across the country, focusing on mid-to-high-end residential products. At the press conference on September 11, Cui Wei once stated that the company has not had a single uncompleted building, a financial bad debt, or a bank overdue payment so far.

;

;"How difficult it is to achieve such results, so why do we have to come out like this on June 21st?" Sang Chunhua once shouted to Cui Wei from a distance.

;

;That night, a drama of "stealing for official seals" was staged in the conference room on the 16th floor of the Pomegranate Group's office building.

;

;In the statement of a company employee signed by "Zhang Yongkai", Cui Wei believed that "Vice Chairman Sang Sir (Sang Chunhua hopes to be as capable and efficient as the Hong Kong police) has violated the company's system and affected the company's operations and other illegal acts ", forcing members of the seal team, including Zhang Yongkai, to stamp documents that could not see the full text.

;

;Afterwards, Cui Wei put the official seal into his pocket and said, "Not only does he have to stamp it, but he also needs to take the seal home. This is his own company, he is the chairman, and this is his right. No one else can control it.”

;

;After struggling until 4 a.m., the members of the seal team were allowed to go home. From this day on, Pomegranate Group announced that Sang Chunhua would be terminated from his labor contract and all his duties.

;

;Cui Wei said that the company’s dismissal of Sang Chunhua was legal and “a serious, legal and regulatory adjustment and defense of corporate governance rights.”

;

;The main reason for the dismissal of Sang Chunhua was that Sang arranged for relatives, classmates, fellow villagers, etc. to enter the company. The company was internally controlled by relevant interest groups. He was sidelined as the chairman, and the company's internal management and cost control were extremely chaotic. . Moreover, Sang had problems with his lifestyle, which caused damage to the company's goodwill.

;

;On September 6, Liu Xia, CEO of Yunhe Variable Group, an investment company, reported Sang Chunhua on Weibo with his real name, saying that he invited many people to participate in unhealthy activities in Beijing on the pretext of eating. I was abused on WeChat and over the phone for dozens of minutes." It was later revealed that Li Guangtian, president of Jiangsu, Zhejiang and Shanghai regions of Pomegranate Group, and Ding Qingwei, president of Jiangsu region, were also involved.

;

;On September 8, Sang Chunhua issued a statement saying: "The dissemination of my unverified and untrue remarks by online platforms and individuals has seriously violated my right to reputation. I demand that the slander be stopped immediately." stigma, and reserves the right to pursue the legal responsibilities of online platforms and individuals. I have entrusted a lawyer to initiate relevant legal procedures."

;

;Faced with Cui Wei's many accusations, Sang Chunhua also held multiple press conferences, Fight back against it.

;

;In addition to disclosing the situation on June 21, Sang Chunhua claimed that the dismissal was without legal decision-making procedures of the company. He also accused Cui Wei to the media of improperly occupying company property and refusing to return it, and installing bugs in the vehicle he was riding in. device.

;

;Also attending the press conference with Sang Chunhua on September 14 was Lin Xinwu, the former general manager of the Risk Control Center and Chairman of the Board of Supervisors of Pomegranate Group. He said that Pomegranate Group launched an A-share listing plan in 2016, and 62 core members paid in 216.8 million yuan as partners to participate in the share reform.

;

;After the A-share listing was blocked, Pomegranate turned to Hong Kong stocks in 2021, but still failed, and the partners’ funds were not returned. It wasn't until the official seal incident broke out on June 21 that Cui Wei, the working partner, "collectively forced the wife to marry", asked for part of the money back. But the five partners, including him, were not only fired, but also did not receive refunds, totaling 33.5 million yuan.

;

;Sang Chunhua also disclosed that Cui Wei had firmly refused to agree to dividends for 25 years, and the two borrowed money from the company when they needed it. In recent years, Cui Wei has borrowed hundreds of millions of yuan from companies in public names, and his whereabouts are unknown. Cui Wei also used company funds to speculate in Shougang stocks, resulting in a cumulative loss of 6 billion yuan.

;

;Cui Wei also accused Sang Chunhua of having "huge and sudden" external personal debts, endangering the company's operational security.

;

;;Apprentice or shareholder? ;

;

;Behind the back-and-forth attacks are actually hidden equity differences between the two parties.

;

;Until August 4, Sang Chunhua still couldn’t enter the office. Downstairs of the company, he held a report on national enterprise credit information disclosure and introduced himself to the camera, saying that he was the director and general manager of Pomegranate Group and held 42% of the shares. The company has only two shareholders, with Cui Wei holding the other 58%.

;

;In the camera, Sang Chunhua has short buzzcut hair and wears a pair of black-rimmed glasses. He called Cui Weilian twice, but no one answered. Then he dialed 110 and claimed to the police, "I am the boss of this company and he has no right to fire me."

;

;In fact, after the shareholding of Pomegranate Group was penetrated, it was two companies registered in Hong Kong, and the national enterprise credit system could not see the shareholding status of the two.

;

;However, Pomegranate Group went public in Hong Kong in 2021. The prospectus obtained by Southern Weekend reporters shows that the company has established an overseas equity structure, with Cui Wei holding 57.42% of the shares, Sang Chunhua holding 41.58%, and investors Chen Jianyong holds 1% of the shares.

;

;Zhang Yonggang has worked at Pomegranate Group for nearly ten years and is still working next to Sang Chunhua. He told Southern Weekend reporters that Chen Jianyong was a friend of Sang Chunhua. He withdrew his shares after the listing failed. Now Cui Wei and Sang Chunhua hold 58% and 42% of the company's shares respectively.

;

;Due to the failure of listing, the prospectus of Pomegranate Group is currently invalid and cannot be viewed.

;

;In the face of the media, Cui Wei, a former geography teacher, always calls Sang Chunhua his "best student", "just like Cao Yunjin to Guo Degang."

;

;He said that he went overseas as a state-owned enterprise in 1993 and founded CITIC Real Estate Brokerage Company in Nanjing the following year (Editor’s note: public information cannot be found) and engaged in second-hand housing real estate brokerage. In 1998, he recruited Sang Chunhua, who was 20 years and 4 months old. At that time, Sang had no real estate sales experience and his monthly salary was 300 yuan.

;

;It was the World Cup in France that year. One night, Sang Chunhua was watching the game alone in the store when he met the owner Cui Wei who came to inspect the store. The two chatted for a long time while watching the game. Choi is 10 years older than Sang. After that, the two went to Qingdao and Beijing together to gradually expand the company.

;

;Cui Wei said that it was not until he transformed the sales agency business into a demutualized company and donated part of his shares to Sang Chunhua free of charge that Sang became a shareholder. Subsequently, the company entered the real estate development business, and he transferred the shares of the sales agency company held by Sang into the development company, and successively granted him the positions of general manager and vice chairman.

;

;Today, the share split is regarded by Cui Wei as a huge mistake, laying the foundation for today's disputes.

;

;But Sang Chunhua did not accept Cui Wei's statement that he was a student and an employee. He claimed that in the past 25 years, "two people started a business and started from scratch."

;

;At the press conference on September 14, Sang Chunhua introduced that he started working in 1996. When he met Cui Wei in 1998, he was already the sales director of a real estate company in Nanjing, doing first-hand housing business. , and it was he who mobilized Cui Wei, who was still doing second-hand housing at the time, to enter first-hand housing.

;

;According to Sang Chunhua, when they went north to start a business in Qingdao, the two had already determined the equity ratio of 70:30. In 2001, the Shandong team was disbanded, and he and Cui Wei came to Beijing again and registered Agile in the same year. At that time, we negotiated shares in Henderson Center and finally reached a ratio of 58:42.

;

;"The so-called gift of shares is nonsense, and not paying for it is even more of a joke." Sang Chunhua said bluntly. Zhang Yonggang provided Agile's industrial and commercial information to Southern Weekend reporters, which showed that the company's registered capital was 10 million, with Cui Wei investing 5.8 million yuan in currency and Sang Chunhua investing 4.2 million yuan in currency.

;

;Zhang Yonggang told Southern Weekend reporters that in 2008, Cui Hesang established Huamei Qiaogoli and transferred the shares of Agile. The ratio of 58:42 was still maintained, which was the predecessor of Pomegranate Group.

;

;At the press conference on September 14, Sang Chunhua said that on September 8, he took the initiative to interview Cui Wei and proposed to end the dispute, but the other party insisted on a 30% premium from the major shareholder. "We still have to grab it."

;

;;Trouble with overseas structures;

;

;The reason why Pomegranate Group has corporate governance chaos is because it involves overseas structures.

;

;Sang Chunhua pointed out that Cui Wei did not agree to dismantle the overseas structure after the company failed to go public in 2021.  

;

; Qichacha shows that Pomegranate Group is 100% owned by Beijing Minjiang Technology Co., Ltd. (hereinafter referred to as Minjiang Technology). The latter’s legal representative is Cui Wei. After the equity penetration, it is owned by two Hong Kong companies. The Hong Kong company is in turn held by a company registered in the British Virgin Islands. Under this offshore structure, neither of the two major shareholders directly holds shares in the country.

;

;Equity lawyer Lu Qinghua once represented equity disputes similar to those of Pomegranate Group and authored the book "Corporate Control". She analyzed to Southern Weekend reporters that the domestic company Pomegranate Group is 100% owned by Minjiang Technology, and Cui Wei, the legal representative of Minjiang Technology, has the right to decide the candidates for the board of directors of Pomegranate Group. In the absence of special provisions in the company's articles of association, the legal representative also has the right to manage the official seal.

;

;Since August 2023, the management of Pomegranate Group has undergone a major change. After dismissing Sang Chunhua and Lin Xinwu, the company added four directors and one supervisor within one day. According to Sang Chunhua, the new directors include Cui Wei’s wife, Zhu Yanhua, who was appointed without his consent as the second shareholder.

;

;In Lu Qinghua’s view, under the overseas equity structure, Sang Chunhua does not directly hold shares of Pomegranate Group. This means that even if Sang Chunhua sues Cui Wei to dismiss him without going through legal procedures, it will be more difficult to win the case.

;

;Zheng Zhigang, a professor at the School of Finance at Renmin University of China who focuses on corporate governance research, holds a different view. He told Southern Weekend reporters that the ownership structure must ultimately restore the individuals who actually invested and reflect the true wishes of the investors. The appointment and removal of company directors require the approval of a majority of shareholders.

;

;However, he also agreed that if litigation is involved under an overseas structure, the actual legal effect of overseas awards may face challenges, and the litigation process may be a difficult tug-of-war.

;

;Zheng Zhigang introduced that the disputes at Pomegranate Group reflected some common issues in the governance of private enterprises. Many private enterprises focus on investment in the early stages of entrepreneurship. The founders are independent of each other and are maintained by family ties, friendships, etc.

;

;After the company becomes bigger, some companies fail to handle the problem of profit distribution through institutional methods such as equity and compensation, or do not pay attention to the formation of a standardized corporate structure by introducing external investors. Problems caused by corporate governance often As a result, it is difficult for its business to last forever.

;

;Affected by the dispute, Pomegranate Group began to face the risk of bank loan withdrawals.

;

;Industrial Bank took the lead in sending a notification letter to Pomegranate Group, requiring it to deposit the remaining 74 million yuan of principal and interest repayable for this year on a 1.8 billion yuan loan into a supervisory account before August 12, 2023. Otherwise, Industrial Bank has the right to declare all loans to expire early and hold the borrower and guarantor responsible for breach of contract.

;

;Pomegranate Group’s 2022 corporate bond annual report shows that as of the end of 2022, Pomegranate Group’s total interest-bearing liabilities were 16.678 billion yuan. Among them, bank loans within one year were 375 million yuan, and trust borrowings within one year were 1.146 billion yuan. A total of three interest-bearing bonds are in existence, with a total amount of 2.916 billion yuan, all of which will mature in 2024.

;

;However, as of the end of 2022, Pomegranate Group’s monetary funds were only 2.864 billion yuan, of which 536 million yuan was a restricted amount.
